The sky is blue because of Rayleigh scattering. As light moves through the atmosphere, most of the longer wavelengths pass straight through. Smaller particles can only scatter shorter wavelengths, and since blue light has a shorter wavelength, it gets scattered in all directions. This is why we see a blue sky most of the time.
The sky is blue.

The sky is blue because air scatters short-wavelength light from the sun more than it scatters longer-wavelength light. Since blue light is at the short-wavelength end of the visible spectrum, it is more strongly scattered in the atmosphere than long-wavelength red light.
